title: Magic — Quick FAQ

playingField.library: Your deck of cards. When you draw, you take the top card into your hand.
playingField.battlefield: Where creatures, artifacts, enchantments and lands sit when played.
playingField.graveyard: Discarded cards. Some effects interact with the graveyard.
playingField.exile: Removed from the game. Typically harder to recover from exile than from graveyard.
playingField.commandZone: Commander cards start here and can be cast from here with commander tax rules.

cardTypes: A quick list: Creature, Instant, Sorcery, Enchantment, Artifact, Land, Planeswalker, Tribal.
mulligan: The first few cards you draw are called your "opening hand". If you don't like it, you SHOULD mulligan, meaning shuffle it back into your library and draw a new set of 7 cards. You want to have at least 3 lands in your opening hand, and something that furthers your game plan. But be careful! The more you mulligan, the less cards you get to start with.
takingATurn: Main phase — play lands, cast spells.
Second main phase — same as first main phase.
readingACard: Top line: name. Mana cost: top-right. Types line: creature/enchantment/etc. Text box: abilities and keywords. Power/Toughness: bottom-right for creatures.
combat: Declare attackers during combat. Defending player declares blockers. Combat damage is assigned and dealt. Watch for instant-speed interaction.
tipsAndTricks: Always play your land for the turn! It's easy to forget, but lands are crucial for casting spells.
Save instant-speed removal for the best targets. Sometimes it's better to wait and see what your opponents play.
Read the cards carefully! Keywords like 'Flying' and 'Trample' matter a lot in combat.
In Commander, politics matter. Sometimes making a deal is better than making an enemy.
Don't be afraid to use your life as a resource. Going from 40 to 30 life isn't as scary as it seems.
Watch what lands your opponents play to figure out what colors they're running.
Your commander can be cast from the command zone, but it costs 2 more mana each time after the first.
Ramp (cards that help you get more mana) is usually a good early play to help you cast bigger spells later.
Card advantage is key: cards that let you draw more cards or get multiple effects are usually powerful.
When in doubt, ask! Everyone was new once, and most players are happy to help explain interactions.
